instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used to predict soil organic matter (SOM) content in topsoil from four major rivers in the Republic of Korea?
Output: The visible and IR spectral was used to predict soil organic matter (SOM) content in topsoil from four major rivers in the Republic of Korea.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to predict soil organic matter (SOM) content in topsoil from four major rivers in the Republic of Korea?
Output: Maximum normalization, Savitzky–Golay first-order derivatives, SNV, and MSC pre-processing techniques were used to predict soil organic matter (SOM) content in topsoil from four major rivers in the Republic of Korea.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the prediction model for soil organic matter in Korea, and how well did it perform ?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the prediction model for SOM content was the coefficient of determination (R-2) and root mean square error. The R-2 value obtained for the SOM content prediction model was 0.706, indicating a moderate level of predictability.

instruction: How were the machine learning models used to predict the SOM content in the topsoil samples collected from the rivers in the Republic of Korea?
Output: The machine learning models, specifically partial least squares regression and support vector regression, were used to predict the soil organic matter (SOM) content in the topsoil samples collected from the rivers in the Republic of Korea. The models were developed using spectroscopic techniques, where the reflection spectrum of each topsoil sample was measured three times in wavelengths ranging from 350 to 2500 nm. The performance of each model was evaluated using the coefficient of determination (R-2) and root mean square error. The SOM content prediction model for the total topsoil had an R-2 value of 0.706, indicating a relatively good predictability of the SOM content.
